segments.source_content: We already featured this in our last issue, but thereâ€™s now a dedicated blog post that greatly explains what itâ€™s all about. A new React Router feature enables you to split your route manifest in chunks. This article explains how it has been integrated in Remix 2.10 and what are the tradeoffs. It turns out a route manifest can grow quite large, and if you donâ€™t split it, it might delay your appâ€™s React hydration because it has to be downloaded upfront. If you have a medium/large Remix or React Router site, Iâ€™d recommend to check the size your route manifest immediately, and think about logical ways to split it, because the size reduction this new feature enable can have a significant perf impact. Shopifyâ€™s initial manifest went from 10MB to 1.9KB! The Docusaurus website manifest is also 200KB and I definitively plan to implement this.

segments.source_content: The Margelo team released an impressive new real-time physically based 3D rendering engine for React Native, based on Google Filament. Itâ€™s GPU-accelerated by Metal/Vulkan, rendered on a separate thread, works with Reanimated, and already supports the New Architecture and Expo. The readme explains well how it differs from existing 3D solutions based on expo-gl (expo-three and react-three-fiber RN). With Skia and Filament, the future looks bright for React Native's 2D/3D capabilities.

segments.source_content: A brand-new solution to create Server Driven UIs in React Native, that allows you to deploy new views on the server without rebuilding/resubmitting your app (or even ship an OTA update). It looks philosophically very close to the React Server Components model, but with slightly different tradeoffs: at the cost of some additional manual wiring, this new solution is framework and language agnostic thanks to a protocol that defines how views are serialized. It's still early days, but it looks promising.

Philosophiquement trÃ¨s proche du modÃ¨le React Server Components, mais avec des compromis lÃ©gÃ¨rement diffÃ©rents : au prix d'un cÃ¢blage manuel supplÃ©mentaire, cette solution est agnostique vis-Ã -vis du framework et du langage grÃ¢ce Ã  un protocole dÃ©finissant la sÃ©rialisation des vues. Encore prÃ©coce, mais prometteur.
translations.en: Une toute nouvelle solution pour crÃ©er des interfaces utilisateur pilotÃ©es par serveur dans React Native, permettant de dÃ©ployer de nouvelles vues cÃ´tÃ© serveur sans reconstruire/resoumettre votre application (ou mÃªme diffuser une mise Ã  jour OTA). Elle est philosophiquement trÃ¨s proche du modÃ¨le des React Server Components, mais avec des compromis lÃ©gÃ¨rement diffÃ©rents : au prix d'un cÃ¢blage manuel supplÃ©mentaire, cette nouvelle solution est agnostique en termes de framework et de langage grÃ¢ce Ã  un protocole dÃ©finissant la sÃ©rialisation des vues. C'est encore le dÃ©but, mais cela semble prometteur.
